text: He told, with secret-piercing eyes,
The tale of Ráma's high emprise,
Each listening ear that shall entice,
A sea of pearls of highest price.
Thus good Válmíki, sage divine,
Rehearsed the tale of Raghu's line,
As Nárad, heavenly saint, before
Had traced the story's outline o'er.
event_type: Nárad outlines the story of Ráma to Válmíki.
lesson_type: The importance of recounting virtuous deeds and epic tales.
dharma: The transmission of sacred narratives to inspire and guide.
summary: This canto describes the heavenly saint Nárad outlining the epic story of Ráma to the sage Válmíki. Following this, Válmíki rehearsed the tale of Ráma's lineage as Nárad had presented its outline. The canto suggests that the story of Ráma holds great value, like 'a sea of pearls of highest price'. It is noted that the first four cantos are introductory and possibly not written by Válmíki himself.

text: The life of Ráma, great and good,
Roaming with Sítá in the wood.
He told, with secret-piercing eyes,
The tale of Ráma's high emprise,
Each listening ear that shall entice,
A sea of pearls of highest price.
Thus good Válmíki, sage divine,
Rehearsed the tale of Raghu's line,
As Nárad, heavenly saint, before
Had traced the story's outline o'er.
He sang of Ráma's princely birth,
His kindness and heroic worth;
His love for all, his patient youth,
His gentleness and constant truth,
event_type: Válmíki presents the virtues and life story of Ráma, based on Nárad's account.
lesson_type: Understanding and appreciating the qualities of a righteous and heroic figure.
dharma: The exposition of righteous conduct through the narrative of Ráma's life.
summary: This canto, titled 'The Argument', details Válmíki's recounting of Ráma's life, drawing from the outline provided by Nárad. Válmíki sings of Ráma's noble birth, his kindness and heroic worth, his universal love, patient youth, gentleness, and constant truth. This canto serves to introduce and establish the key attributes of the central protagonist of the epic.

text: When to the end the tale was brought, Rose in the sages mind the thought Now who throughout this earth will go, And tell it forth that all may know? As thus he mused with anxious breast, Behold, in hermits raiment dressed, Kuá and Lava56 came to greet Their master and embrace his feet. The twins he saw, that princely pair Sweet-voiced, who dwelt beside him there None for the task could be more fit, For skilled were they in Holy Writ And so the great Rámáyan, fraught With lore divine, to these he taught The lay whose verses sweet and clear Take with delight the listening ear, That tell of Sítás noble life And RávaGs fall in battle strife. Great joy to all who hear they bring, Sweet to recite and sweet to sing. For musics sevenfold notes are there, And triple measure,57 wrought with care With melody and tone and time, And flavours58 that enhance the rime
themes: the role of bards and storytellers
the power of narrative and music
event_type: Válmíki chooses and trains Kuá and Lava to be the rhapsodists of the Ramayana.
lesson_type: The importance of spreading knowledge and the power of oral tradition.
dharma: The preservation and transmission of sacred narratives through skilled recitation.
summary: This canto describes Válmíki's contemplation on how the completed tale of Ráma will be disseminated. As he pondered this, Kuá and Lava, a 'princely pair' known for their sweet voices and skill in Holy Writ, approached him. Válmíki recognised them as the most suitable individuals to be the rhapsodists of the great Ramayana and taught them the epic. The canto highlights that the verses are 'sweet and clear' and recount 'Sítá's noble life and RávaG's fall in battle strife', bringing 'great joy' to listeners through recitation and song, incorporating musical elements. Kuá and Lava are identified as the twin sons of Ráma and Sítá, who were born after Ráma had repudiated Sítá and were raised in Válmíki's hermitage.

characters_summary.name: Válmíki
characters_summary.role: The sage who composed the Ramayana and sought worthy individuals to disseminate it.

characters_summary.name: Kuá
characters_summary.role: One of the twin sons of Ráma and Sítá, raised by Válmíki and chosen to be a rhapsodist of the Ramayana.

characters_summary.name: Lava
characters_summary.role: The other twin son of Ráma and Sítá, also raised by Válmíki and chosen as a rhapsodist.

characters_summary.name: Sítá
characters_summary.role: The mother of Kuá and Lava, whose 'noble life' is a part of the epic tale.

This meeting is also referred to as 'The Meeting' in the index on page 732 [1]. It is further identified as the 'Bharat-Miláp or meeting with Bharat' in the context of dramatic representations of Ráma's return [2].

summary: **Canto CIV of Book II is titled 'The Meeting With The Queens'** [6]. This suggests that either Ráma (and perhaps Sítá and Lakshman) meet with the queens of Ayodhyá (Kausalyá, Sumitrá, and possibly Kaikeyí) or Bharat, upon his return with the news of Dasaratha's death, meets with them in the forest. Given the sequence, a meeting in the forest is more likely. Kausalyá's lament at Ráma's departure was mentioned earlier [7, 13-15]. Sumitrá's speech offering counsel was also noted [14, 16].

Given the context of Dasaratha's death and Bharat's desire for Ráma to return and rule, this speech is likely to be Ráma's explanation of his unwavering commitment to fulfilling his father's vow of exile, despite the changed circumstances. Ráma's truthfulness and commitment to his father's decree have been mentioned previously [3, 17-19].

This act typically symbolizes Bharat agreeing to rule Ayodhyá as Ráma's representative during his fourteen years of exile. The sandals would thus serve as a powerful symbol of Ráma's authority and Bharat's commitment to duty in his brother's absence.

Nandigrám was the village where Bharat chose to reside and rule from during Ráma's exile, refusing to occupy the throne in Ayodhyá itself. This act symbolizes his deep respect and devotion to Ráma, and his commitment to serving as a temporary regent awaiting his brother's return [4]. His life there would likely be depicted as simple and austere, focused solely on upholding his duty.

characters_summary.role: Returning with her husband after her rescue.

event_type: The formal departure of Ráma, Sítá, and their retinue from Lanká.
lesson_type: The significance of beginnings after long periods of struggle. The bittersweet nature of farewells when anticipating joyous reunions.
dharma: **Raja Dharma** (duty of a king) to return to his kingdom and his people. **Sneha Dharma** (dharma of affection) in the farewells exchanged.
summary: **Canto CXXIV, 'The Departure', describes the actual commencement of Ráma, Sítá, Lakshman, and their allies' journey from Lanká back to Ayodhyá.** This canto would detail the farewells to Vibhishan and his court, and the initial stages of their travel.

characters_summary.name: Ráma
characters_summary.role: Leading the return journey to Ayodhyá.

characters_summary.name: Sítá
characters_summary.role: Accompanied by her husband on their way home.

characters_summary.name: Vibhishan
characters_summary.role: The newly consecrated king of Lanká, bidding farewell.

event_type: The arrival of Ráma, Sítá, and Lakshman in Ayodhyá.
lesson_type: The ultimate joy of returning home after hardship. The importance of welcoming and celebrating the return of the righteous.
dharma: **Raja Dharma** (duty of a king) fulfilled as Ráma returns to his kingdom and people. **Praja Dharma** (duty of the subjects) to welcome their rightful ruler.
summary: **Canto CXXV, 'The Return', culminates in the arrival of Ráma, Sítá, and Lakshman in Ayodhyá.** This would be a moment of immense joy and celebration as they are reunited with Bharat, Kausalyá, and the other queens, as well as the citizens of Ayodhyá, marking the end of their fourteen-year exile.

characters_summary.name: Ráma
characters_summary.role: The righteous prince returning to his kingdom after his long exile and victory.

characters_summary.name: Sítá
characters_summary.role: Returning home with her husband, her honour restored.

characters_summary.name: Bharat
characters_summary.role: The devoted brother who ruled in Ráma's stead, welcoming his return.

event_type: Bharat being comforted after Ráma's return and the end of his long wait.
lesson_type: The rewards of loyalty and devotion. The joy of reunion after hardship.
dharma: **Bhratri Dharma** (duty towards brothers) fulfilled through Ráma's return and Bharat's steadfastness. **Sneha Dharma** (dharma of affection) evident in their reunion.
summary: **Canto CXXVI, 'Bharat Consoled', likely depicts the emotional reunion between Ráma and Bharat.** After years of separation and Bharat's dedicated rule in Ráma's absence, this canto would focus on Bharat being relieved and happy at Ráma's return and Ráma's comforting words and actions towards him.
characters: Potentially Kausalyá and other family members

characters_summary.name: Ráma
characters_summary.role: Returning king offering comfort and affection to his devoted brother.

characters_summary.name: Bharat
characters_summary.role: The brother who faithfully ruled in Ráma's absence, now experiencing the joy of his return and being consoled.

event_type: Ráma sending a message, likely to allies or key figures.
lesson_type: The importance of communication and keeping promises, even after achieving a major goal. The value of reliable messengers.
dharma: **Raja Dharma** (duty of a king) to communicate with and care for his allies and subjects. **Mitra Dharma** (duty towards friends/allies) in maintaining connections after the war.
summary: **Canto CXXVII, 'Ráma's Message', probably involves Ráma sending news of his safe return to those who supported him during his exile and the war.** This could include messages to Sugríva, Vibhishan, or other important figures, expressing gratitude and reassuring them of the future.
characters: Likely recipients like Sugríva and Vibhishan (mentioned in previous cantos [1])

characters_summary.name: Ráma
characters_summary.role: The king sending important messages after his return.

characters_summary.name: Hanumán (likely)
characters_summary.role: A trusted messenger conveying Ráma's words.

event_type: Hanumán recounting the events of the search for Sítá and the war.
lesson_type: The importance of remembering past struggles and the efforts of those who helped. The impact of a faithful retelling of events.
dharma: **Seva Dharma** (dharma of service) exemplified by Hanumán's actions, now being narrated. The importance of truthfully recounting events (**Satya Dharma**).
summary: **Canto CXXVIII, 'Hanumán's Story', likely features Hanumán narrating the entire saga of Sítá's abduction, the search, the battle in Lanká, and their eventual return to Ayodhyá.** This would be a comprehensive recounting for those who were not present for all the events, or a way to relive the journey.

characters_summary.name: Hanumán
characters_summary.role: The faithful servant and key player recounting the epic story.

characters_summary.name: Ráma
characters_summary.role: Listening to the retelling of his own trials and triumphs.

characters_summary.name: Bharat
characters_summary.role: Learning or reliving the events that occurred during Ráma's exile.

canto: Canto CXXIX. The Meeting With Bharat.
event_type: A formal or significant meeting between Ráma and Bharat upon Ráma's return.
lesson_type: The ideal relationship between brothers, characterized by love, respect, and a sense of duty. The smooth transition of leadership.
dharma: **Bhratri Dharma** (duty towards brothers) highlighted in their interaction. **Raja Dharma** (duty of a king) in the context of welcoming back the rightful ruler.
summary: **Canto CXXIX, 'The Meeting With Bharat', likely describes a more formal and significant meeting between Ráma and Bharat upon Ráma's arrival in or near Ayodhyá.** This could detail the exchange of greetings, expressions of joy, and the formal acknowledgement of Ráma's return to his rightful place as king. It might follow Hanumán's earlier message (Canto CXXVII inferred) preparing Bharat for Ráma's arrival.
characters: Potentially Kausalyá, other queens, and important ministers/citizens

characters_summary.name: Ráma
characters_summary.role: The returning king meeting his brother after a long separation.

characters_summary.name: Bharat
characters_summary.role: The brother who ruled in his stead, now formally welcoming Ráma back.

themes: Coronation and the establishment of reign
The beginning of a new era
event_type: The formal coronation ceremony of Ráma as the King of Ayodhyá.
lesson_type: The importance of righteous leadership and the stability it brings. The joy and celebration that follow the restoration of order and justice.
dharma: **Raja Dharma** (duty of a king) being formally undertaken by Ráma. **Praja Dharma** (duty of the subjects) in their participation and acceptance of their rightful ruler. **Satya Dharma** (the dharma of truth and righteousness) prevailing with Ráma's ascendance to the throne.
summary: **Canto CXXX, 'The Consecration', likely depicts the grand coronation ceremony where Ráma is formally installed as the King of Ayodhyá.** This would be a momentous occasion marked by Vedic rituals, the presence of esteemed sages and citizens, and widespread celebrations signifying the return of a just and righteous rule.

characters_summary.name: Ráma
characters_summary.role: The righteous prince being consecrated as the King of Ayodhyá.

characters_summary.name: Sítá
characters_summary.role: Likely present as the queen consort during Ráma's coronation.

characters_summary.name: Bharat
characters_summary.role: The devoted brother witnessing and supporting Ráma's consecration.

characters_summary.name: Vasishtha (likely)
characters_summary.role: The revered sage officiating the coronation ceremony.
